config.description: Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol Global Configurations

disable-virtual-router-mac-address.description: Use this attribute to enable or disable Virtual MAC (VMAC). This affects all VRRP groups in a router. On a single network segment, multiple VRRP groups can be configured, each using a different VMAC. The use of VMAC addressing allows for faster switchover when a backup router assumes the master role. When this attribute is used to enable a VMAC, the virtual router forwards packets with a special-purpose multicast VMAC address (0:0:5e:0:01:VR_ID). Otherwise, it forwards with interface physical address.The VMAC address is assigned to a router interface at the time the VRRP group is enabled in the router.

vrrp-v2-compatible.description: Use this attribute to enable or disable backward-compatibility feature. When enabled, both VRRPv3 and VRRPv2 interoperation are supported.

ipv4-exclude-pseudo-header.description: This command excludes the pseudo-header in IPv4 VRRPv3 checksum calculation on the VRRP group

state.description: Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol Global State

disable-virtual-router-mac-address.description: Use this attribute to enable or disable Virtual MAC (VMAC). This affects all VRRP groups in a router. On a single network segment, multiple VRRP groups can be configured, each using a different VMAC. The use of VMAC addressing allows for faster switchover when a backup router assumes the master role. When this attribute is used to enable a VMAC, the virtual router forwards packets with a special-purpose multicast VMAC address (0:0:5e:0:01:VR_ID). Otherwise, it forwards with interface physical address.The VMAC address is assigned to a router interface at the time the VRRP group is enabled in the router.

vrrp-v2-compatible.description: Use this attribute to enable or disable backward-compatibility feature. When enabled, both VRRPv3 and VRRPv2 interoperation are supported.

ipv4-exclude-pseudo-header.description: This command excludes the pseudo-header in IPv4 VRRPv3 checksum calculation on the VRRP group

state.description: Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol Session State

new-master.description: Virtual Router Redundancy New Master Notification

protocol-error.description: Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol Error Notification

packet-error.description: Virtual Router Redundancy Packet Error Notification

state.description: Virtual Router Global Errors state

checksum-error.description: Number of VRRP packets received with checksum error

version-error.description: Number of VRRP packets received with version error

invalid-virtual-router-id.description: Number of VRRP packets received with invalid virtual router id

options.description: use this attribute to specify debugging options for VRRP

state.description: Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol State

options.description: use this attribute to specify debugging options for VRRP

terminal-debug-status.description: Use this attribute to retrieve debugging options enabled for VRRP

ipv4-instances.description: Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol IPV4 Instances

config.description: Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol IPV4 Instances Configuration

state.description: Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol IPV4 Instances State

interfaces.description: Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol IPV4 Interfaces

interface-name.description: Use this attribute to configure an VRRP routing process for an interface.

config.description: Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol IPV4 Interface Configuration

interface-name.description: Use this attribute to configure a VRRP routing process for an interface.

disable-preempt-mode.description: Use this attribute to configure preempt mode. If set to true, the highest priority backup is always the master when the default master is unavailable. If set to false, a higher priority backup does not preempt a lower priority backup which is acting as master

priority.description: Use this attribute to configure the VRRP router priority within the virtual router. Priority determines the role that each VRRP router plays and what happens if the master virtual router fails. If a VRRP router owns the IP address of the virtual router and the IP address of the physical interface, this router functions as the master virtual router

preempt-delay.description: Use this attribute to set a switch-back delay timer for the master VRRP router. This feature prevents the original master VRRP router from transitioning back to the master state after coming back online until the configured delay timer has expired.

advertisement-interval.description: Use this attribute to configure the advertisement interval of a virtual router. This is the length of time, in seconds, between each advertisement sent from the master to its backup(s). The master virtual router sends VRRP advertisements to other VRRP routers in the same group. The advertisements communicate the priority and state of the master virtual router. The VRRP advertisements are encapsulated in IP packets and sent to the multicast address assigned to the VRRP group (224.0.0.18). Advertisements are sent every second by default.

disable-accept-mode.description: Use this attribute to enable accept mode for the session

vrrp-v2-compatible.description: Use this attribute to enable or disable the backward-compatibility feature

ipv4-exclude-pseudo-header.description: Use this attribute to excludes the pseudo-header in IPv4 VRRPv3 checksum calculation

authentication-data.description: Use this attribute to include authentication simple text

primary-ip-address.description: Use this attribute to set the operational-ip address for the virtual router

mlag-active-standby.description: Use this attribute to set active-standby mlag mode

authentication-data.description: Use this attribute to include authentication simple text

primary-ip-address.description: Use this attribute to set the operational-ip address for the virtual router

mlag-active-standby.description: Use this attribute to set active-standby mlag mode

enable.description: Use this attribute to enable a VRRP session on the router (to make it participate in virtual routing). To make any changes to the VRRP configuration, first disable the router from participating in virtual routing using the disable command

enable.description: Use this attribute to enable a VRRP session on the router (to make it participate in virtual routing). To make any changes to the VRRP configuration, first disable the router from participating in virtual routing using the disable command

ip-address-owner.description: Use this attribute to set the virtual IP address for the VRRP virtual router as VRRP Owner. This is the IP address used by end hosts to address their default gateway.

ip-address-owner.description: Use this attribute to set the virtual IP address for the VRRP virtual router as VRRP Owner. This is the IP address used by end hosts to address their default gateway.

interface-tracking-name.description: Use this command to enable the VRRP circuit failover feature.
